docs.lead_paragraph: After blocking it for more than a decade, the State Senate will pass a hate crimes bill on Wednesday, leaders said today, making it all but certain that some version of the bill will become law this year. The Senate bill provides for longer prison sentences for various crimes when victims are singled out because they are gay or lesbian, in addition to those victimized on the basis of race, religion, sex or age. That settles the longstanding dispute over the inclusion of gays that had prevented the bill's passage. If enacted, lawmakers said, it would be the first time that the words ''gay'' and ''lesbian'' or the phrase ''sexual orientation'' appear anywhere in the dozens of volumes of New York State laws.

headline.main: State Senate To Pass Bill On Hate Crime

docs.abstract: New York State Senate will pass hate crimes bill making it all but certain that some version of bill will become law this year; Senate bill provides for longer prison sentences for various crimes when victims are singled out because they are gay or lesbian, in addition to those victimized on basis of race, religion, sex or age (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: FOR a long time, the image of the typical Internet user was a heterosexual white male younger than 40. Although this characterization was mostly true, the Web is now becoming a thriving marketplace for a wider range of people. As the economic and political influence of Asian-Americans, Hispanics, African-Americans and gay men and lesbians increases, so does their presence on the Web. Technology is also allowing millions of people with disabilities to go online. Not surprisingly, a growing number of sites are serving these communities as they contour the Web to their own needs.

headline.main: The Web's User Profile Undergoes a Broad Transformation

docs.abstract: Web is now becoming thriving marketplace for wide range of people, not just younger, white, heterosexual males; growing number of sites serving minority communities noted; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Investor-owned health maintenance organizations were financially damaged by Medicare premium cuts enacted in the Balanced Budget Act of 1997; therefore, they are leaving key markets to seek more profitable lines of business (front page, June 3). Because the Medicare premium is based on its component parts, the largest of which is hospital care, an inadequate premium reflects inadequate payments to hospitals.
docs.abstract: Letter from Kenneth E Raske (Greater New York Hospital Association) says departure of health maintenance organizations from Medicare market (June 3 article) can be traced to the excessive Medicare premium cuts enacted in Balanced Budget Act of 1997; cartoon

keywords.value: HEALTH MAINTENANCE ORGANIZATIONS AND MANAGED CARE

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: You report that more health maintenance organizations will soon pull out of Medicare, disrupting insurance coverage for hundreds of thousands of elderly people (''More H.M.O.'s Quit Medicare, Stirring Turmoil,'' front page, June 3). Is anyone really surprised? Health maintenance organizations, regarded as the solution to America's health care cost problem, are behaving in a most predictable fashion. After all, if we set up a system whose main mission is to satisfy boards of directors and to provide acceptable profits to stockholders, how can we expect that patient concerns will enter into the consciousness of the providers?
docs.abstract: Irving R Schwartz letter says it should be no surprise that health maintenance organizations are dropping Medicare patients from their rolls (June 3 article); cartoon

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: What a shame that health maintenance organizations are ''forced'' to get out of Medicare because they can't turn a substantial profit with the regulations imposed on them by the government (front page, June 3). That only proves that the only way they can stay in business is by making their own rules and imposing hardships on patients and providers.

docs.lead_paragraph: For six years, Sean Keilen pursued one of the job market's most elusive prey: a bona fide, salaried job as a college professor. Mr. Keilen, a Ph.D. candidate in English Renaissance poetry at Stanford University, sent out 11 applications and sat through interviews with 22 people at four colleges.
docs.abstract: Tight labor market also exists in academia, area in which Bureau of Labor Statistics projects number of college and university professors will surge 23 percent, to 1,060,000 in 2008 from 865,000 in 1998; job prospects are improving not only in traditionally high-demanding fields such as business, but also in social sciences; several factors are driving demand for more professors, including rising enrollments and growing number of retirements in teaching; example of Sean Keilen, PhD candidate. who received teaching position at University of Pennsylvania after sending out numerous applications and undergoing interviews with 22 people at four colleges, cited; his photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton will order Medicare to start covering most of the costs of clinical trials testing the value of new drugs and medical treatments for millions of elderly and disabled people, administration officials said today. Mr. Clinton plans to take the action by issuing an ''executive memorandum'' on Wednesday, the officials said.

headline.main: Clinton to Order Medicare to Pay New Costs

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton will issue 'executive memorandum' ordering Medicare to begin covering most of costs of clinical trials testing value of new drugs and medical treatments for millions of elderly and disabled; people with chronic diseases have long sought such a policy change; White House says change is needed to increase number of elderly who participate in studies on ways to prevent, detect and treat variety of ailments (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In the 1960's, Medicare was designed to provide medical care as a social good. In the 1980's, Medicare started its transition toward a managed-care model. Now, managed-care providers are pulling out of Medicare in more than half the states (front page, June 3). These companies, usually more concerned with profit than with social good, have discovered that providing good medical care does not translate into big bucks.
docs.abstract: Christopher Cherney letter says withdrawal of managed-care providers from Medicare market (June 3 article) demonstrates that the government is the best provider of health care to the disabled and the elderly; cartoon

docs.lead_paragraph: With American support, the World Bank is expected to approve on Tuesday a $3.5 billion project to develop an oil pipeline in Chad and Cameroon in West Africa, despite widespread concerns about the potential for corruption and environmental damage. The Clinton administration will vote in favor of World Bank sponsorship after specifying an unusually detailed list of safeguards that officials hope will earmark the oil revenues for development projects and ward off abuse, a senior American official said today.

headline.main: $3.5 Billion Africa Pipeline Expected to Pass

docs.abstract: World Bank, with American support, is expected to approve $3.5 billion project to develop oil pipeline in Chad and Cameroon in West Africa, despite widespread concerns about potential for corruption and environmental damage; Clinton administration will vote in favor of bank's sponsorship after specifying unusually detailed list of safeguards officials hope will earmark oil revenues for development projects; proposed 663-mile pipeline will link oil fields in landlocked Chad to Atlantic coast of Cameroon; map (M)
docs.snippet: With American support, the World Bank is expected to approve on Tuesday a $3.5 billion project to develop an oil pipeline in Chad and Cameroon in West Africa, despite widespread concerns about the potential for corruption and environmental damage.   ...

docs.lead_paragraph: Evolution has not always come up with things people consider wonderful. Note mosquitoes, sickle cell anemia and the killer instinct. But according to evolutionary theory, there is a reason for everything that has evolved. However obnoxious it may seem, somehow it enhances survival. And so it seems that survival is the likely reason for morning sickness, survival not just of the unborn child but also of the pregnant woman who must bear the burden of its prenatal development. That is the conclusion of two Cornell University evolutionary biologists after examining the results of nearly 80,000 successful and unsuccessful pregnancies, correlating their findings with the incidence of morning sickness and the development during early pregnancy of food aversions and cravings.

headline.main: What Could Be Good About Morning Sickness? Plenty

docs.abstract: Jane Brody Personal Health article on research suggesting that morning sickness so common in early pregnancy is actually body's way of keeping women away from potentially contamined foods at time when fetus is especially vulnerable; Samuel M Flaxman and Dr Paul W Sherman of Cornell report that nausea and vomiting helps protect both mother and fetus from toxins that can lurk in in meat, fish, poultry and eggs, which are also foods to which pregnant women develop most aversions; women who suffer from morning sickness also have fewer miscarriages; graphs (M)
